description: Easy - Context and Background: Who Were the Samnites?

questions.question: What major internal Roman conflict was finally resolved by the Licinian Laws of 367 BCE, allowing Rome to focus outward?
options: The conflict between the military and civilian government
The Conflict of the Orders between patricians and plebeians
The dispute between rich and poor citizens over land distribution
The power struggle between the Senate and the consuls

questions.question: How long did the Samnite Wars span, and how many major conflicts occurred during this period?
options: About 30 years with two major wars
Over 50 years with three major conflicts
About 20 years with multiple small skirmishes
Nearly 100 years with continuous warfare

questions.question: Why did Rome find the Samnites a more difficult challenge than the Etruscans, whom Rome had previously defeated?
options: Etruscans were militarily superior but lacked Roman discipline
Rome had defeated Etruscans when they were in decline, but encountered Samnites at the height of their power
Samnites had superior tactical flexibility and better ability to adapt to terrain
Rome was much weaker by the time it fought Samnites

questions.question: Where were the Samnites primarily located in Italy?
options: In the northern territories beyond the Alps with the Gauls
In the coastal regions of western Italy near modern Rome
In the mountainous regions of central and southern Italy
On the islands of Sicily and Sardinia

questions.question: Why was Samnite mountainous territory a military advantage against Rome?
options: Mountains provided natural fortifications that favored Samnite tactics
Mountains prevented the use of any weapons or military formations
The terrain allowed Samnites to use the same tactics as Romans
Mountains made all military advantages irrelevant

questions.question: What was the primary difference between Etruscan and Samnite military strength in the 4th century BCE?
options: Etruscans were stronger militarily but Samnites had better navy
Samnites had no military tradition while Etruscans were professional soldiers
Both were equally strong but fought on different continents
Etruscans were in decline while Samnites were at the height of their power
questions.text_reference: Section 2: Why the Samnites Were More Dangerous

questions.question: What was one key aspect of Samnite military culture?
options: Young men avoided military training in favor of merchant careers
Samnite warriors were trained to fight only in naval battles
Young Samnite men underwent military training and competed for honor through martial prowess
The Samnites relied entirely on foreign mercenaries for their army

questions.question: What wealthy region lay between Samnite territory and Rome, making it a source of conflict?
options: Etruria
Campania
Sicily
The Latin plains
questions.text_reference: Section 2: Why Rome and Samnium Collided

questions.question: How were Samnite city-states organized compared to Etruscan city-states?
options: Samnite city-states were unified under one monarch while Etruscans were independent
Both were identical in organization and had no differences
Samnite city-states had stronger cohesion and could unite for common defense, unlike fragmented Etruscan cities
Samnite city-states had no military organization whatsoever

questions.question: What immediately triggered Rome's decision to go to war with Samnium in 343 BCE?
options: Roman ambition to achieve immediate dominance over all Italian territories and peoples
Samnite military raids and attacks targeting Greek colonies throughout the Mediterranean region
Appeals from Rome's Campanian allies requesting protection against Samnite territorial aggression
A series of disputes between Rome and Samnium over Mediterranean trade route control
questions.text_reference: Section 2: Why Rome and Samnium Collided
